Our work utilized the dataset approach to explore the subjective interpretation of LMs' generative capabilities for interactive writing in the context of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI).
The current paper that aims to design reusable and expandable datasets that capture the writing process.
A future research that can expand the study and dataset to different writing tasks, prompts, and writers using the same user interface and interaction design.
Our work consulted with amateur writers.
Our work aimed to assess whether Dramatron "contributes new ideas to writing" or "merely expand[s] on [the writer's] existing ideas".
Our work investigated interface design factors and interactions with writing assistants that support inspiration and story writing.
Our work that have studied collaborative authoring tools in the domain of document editing.
AI-assisted writing with large language models for probing the model's capabilities as a writing collaborator.
A prior work in story writing that provided users with a paragraph of text which they could further edit.
Our work studied how people collaborate with different types of AI systems in different task contexts.
Our work created a dataset of instances from writers working with GPT-3 to enable exploring its promises for interaction design.
Our work suggest that advanced language models may provide ideas and inspiration beyond increasing text input efficiency.

Our work used LanguageTool to identify grammatical errors in the responses and found that responses from the message-level suggestions condition had the lowest error rate, while the control condition had the highest error rate.
Our work presented CoAuthor, a dataset designed to reveal GPT-3's capabilities in assisting creative and argumentative writing.
Our work focused on longer phrase suggestions.
Our work showed multiple suggestions are shown as popup lists of about three to six entries.
Our work also used a design where users explicitly request suggestions with a hotkey.
Our work implicitly chose to only use diegetic information as input to the language model when the UI did not explicitly afford text prompts.
Our work had a comparable rate of participants accepting suggestions with multiple suggestions and an explicit request via the tab key.
A recent work that has shown high interest in interaction designs where users explicitly request suggestions.
Our work had participants spend 11 minutes with each UI feature across the writing tasks.
Prior related work that used an online setup to collect logging data from interactions of many people.
Recent studies that have used writing tasks from writer communities and custom tasks in their research.
Our work provided guidelines for addressing common difficulties that DHH individuals may encounter during videoconferencing, such as providing visual and haptic feedback.
Our work emphasized the usefulness of participatory design workshops in uncovering the unique needs and preferences of DHH stakeholders.
Our work highlighted limitations for signed communication in videoconferencing environments for DHH users.
Our work explored the role of platform infrastructure on accessibility for Deaf and Hard of Hearing (DHH) people in the context of sign language use.
A recent work that highlighted the shortcomings of current videoconferencing technologies in supporting the needs of Deaf and hard of hearing workers.

The current research paper that brings careful consideration of Deaf cultural context to interview and design methods, following Bauman's call to avoid privileging speech over sign and hearing over deafness.

The current work that focuses on commercially available video conferencing platforms for freelance interpreters and offers new insights into how these platforms can facilitate interpreter-mediated communication.
The current paper that explores the design of commercial, widely used VC platforms instead of bespoke video-based ASL access.
Our work identified key accessibility barriers faced by participants in the current paper and served as a starting point for the co-design discussion and tasks.

A prior study that identified multiple VC access gaps experienced by d/Deaf signers and ASL interpreters and highlighted the broader social implications of inadequate VC access for the diversity of d/Deaf signers.
A study that shared experiences of signers, reinforcing Young et al.'s notion of the "translated Deaf self" and how VC design prioritizes the voicing interpreter's video over the signer's.

The current research paper that includes a diverse research team with Deaf researchers, ASL interpreters, hearing accessibility researchers, and a hearing HCI researcher, aiming to increase cultural and linguistic accessibility and build trust with the Deaf community.
Our work focused on DHH-hearing communication.
Our work focused on multi-person collaborative systems for DHH people, especially in online settings, and informed the design of visual display features.
Our work aims to support d/DHH individuals' communication online and recognizes that most videoconferencing technology was designed with hearing norms in mind.
Our work discusses the lack of support for visual communication in online settings, including experiences of visual dispersion and the negative impact of 2D virtual space on a 3D spatial language.
A large body of work that also highlights the importance of accessible ICTs for the DHH population.

Our work examined the accessibility of videoconferencing for the d/Deaf and hard of hearing community, highlighting unique challenges such as getting attention, turn-taking, and managing visual attention.
Our work highlight the need for broader non-verbal communication channels in videoconferencing.
Our work focused on the better management of visual attention in virtual meetings for DHH individuals, but not for people who stutter.
Our work found exhaustion and dissatisfaction from video conferencing meetings, which could reinforce the negative impact of stuttering on people who stutter.
Our work emphasized the multiplied difficulty in turn taking for DHH individuals.

Our work demonstrates how the synchronicity of video and audio streams in videoconferencing systems makes it difficult for populations such as DHH and people who stutter to have a turn in conversations and how the speech-activated speaker view marginalizes people with no or reduced speech.
Our work found that DHH users struggle with auto-generated captions on videoconferencing platforms when the audio quality is poor.
Our work discussed the difficulties faced by Deaf and hard of hearing individuals in managing delay during remote meetings.

Our work complements previous research on motivations and concerns regarding data sharing, and adds new dimensions by enabling potential data contributors to reflect on the contexts of sharing data sourced from settings where the technology is being deployed.
Our work provided a realistic data contribution scenario and exposed participants to the value of AI data for training and testing.
Our work was referenced multiple times in the interviews to explore participants' understanding of benefits, risks, and contexts related to sharing study data.

Our work explored the factors considered by participants when reasoning about sharing their data, asked for actions from different stakeholders to mitigate risks, and had participants rate approaches to data sharing on a Likert scale.
The current paper that adopts frequencies and median as measures of central tendency for Likert scale data, following recommendations from Sullivan and Artino, 2013.
Our work conducted an interview where the order of questions proceeded from benefits to risks to underlying elements behind the decision to share, potentially impacting participants' responses.

A prior study that focused on a specific disability community, country, and context, making it challenging to obtain generalizable implications and not providing insights on the concerns and motivations for the Deaf community.
Our work the current paper's findings are connected to, in order to contribute to conversations and initiatives on responsible practices for stewarding accessibility datasets.
Our work identified instances in which sharing study data could lead to beneficial outcomes related to the improvement and evaluation of object recognition technology.
Our work explored participants' awareness and reactions towards potential risks in data sharing, particularly focusing on concerns about the secondary use of data and potential negative consequences.
Our work sourced datasets from the blind community, similar to the participants in the current study.
Our work raised minimal concerns for the given scenario but also highlighted some degree of concerns around the ethics of data use.
Our work found that participants were uncomfortable sharing photos of medication, which was rated low on the comfort scale, compared to other types of objects.
Our work found participants were unsure of the usefulness of certain demographic information, such as height/weight or dominant hand, in AI datasets.

Our work conducted a study on data stewards and participants' expectations regarding actions to mitigate risks in sharing study data and how data stewards should restrict the use cases of the data being shared.

Our work asked participants, as potential data contributors, what actions they could take to protect themselves from risks and found that participants were careful about what data they would be sharing.

Our work indicated the importance of supportive materials and communication to help potential data contributors assess the benefit-risk tradeoffs, and showed participants' reluctance to share demographic information as it was deemed 'not relevant' for AI development.
Our work revealed the participants' difficulty in directly addressing the nuances of risk assessment and finding it hard to imagine critical scenarios.

Our work used a study method revealing partial effects by providing an opportunity for participants to engage more deeply in assessing the impacts and implications of data sharing, and analyzing rules and tradeoff assessments.
Our work found that many participants were hesitant to contribute their study data for ambiguous purposes or purposes that didn't align with their perceived benefits, revealing notions of "distrust."
Our work found participants wanted to be kept informed about actions taken regarding their data and desired complete disclosure of how their data are being used.
